sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kata Nagygyörgy & Diana Lakatos)
articles.description: This article is a case study of how the platformOS team has researched, developed, and iteratively adjusted their onboarding processes over more than three years to eventually create the multiple award winning developer experience they provide today.
articles.title: Developing An Award-Winning Onboarding Process (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: CSS is constantly evolving, and some cool and useful properties either go completely unnoticed or are not talked about as much as others for some reason or another. In this article, we’ll cover a fraction of those CSS properties and selectors.
articles.title: Lesser-Known And Underused CSS Features In 2022

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Greg Dickens)
articles.description: In this article, we will see step-by-step how you can get the best of customization with easy admin by using Ghost as a headless CMS for a Gatsby static site — everything for free.
articles.title: The Ultimate Free Solo Blog Setup With Ghost And Gatsby

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Benjamin Ajibade)
articles.description: In this article, Benjamin Ajibade introduces Kubernetes to front-end engineers and explaines why Kubernetes is integral in a production-ready microservice architecture. Some key terms that are important for team collaboration will be discussed and conclude the post with a quick deployment to getting started as a beginner.
articles.title: Kubernetes For Frontend Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we ask how one man can go from designing websites for local bands to heading up Google Fonts Knowledge. Smashing’s Vitaly Friedman talks to Elliot Jay Stocks to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 46 With Vitaly Friedman: Who Is Elliot Jay Stocks?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nick Babich)
articles.description: Let’s take a closer look at how you can create your very own WordPress site up and running created and hosted with the Elementor Cloud Website.
articles.title: The Modern Way To Create And Host A WordPress Site

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sean Roberts)
articles.description: What makes the underused `Server-Timing` header uniquely powerful among all other response headers? We’ll rethink the expectation for using it exclusively for timing and see fast solutions for hard-to-solve monitoring challenges.
articles.title: Rethinking Server-Timing As A Critical Monitoring Tool

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Gerry McGovern)
articles.description: We waste so much today. One way of focusing on what truly matters is by identifying Top Tasks for yourself. Learn how to make tough decisions by focusing on the real, quantifiable evidence that will help create a better experience for your users.
articles.title: Top Tasks: To Focus On What Matters You Must De-Focus On What Doesn’t

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dan Shappir)
articles.description: In this article, Dan Shappir analyzes the performance cost associated with various frameworks and explains the wide variety of framework and platform choices that are currently available to front-end and fullstack developers.
articles.title: How To Use Google CrUX To Analyze And Compare The Performance Of JS Frameworks

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Denis Studennikov)
articles.description: In this article, we will be taking a closer look at a design case study and discuss possible reasons why its customers abandon their online shopping carts and what solutions are recommended in each particular case.
articles.title: How Even Small UX Changes Can Result In An Increase In Conversion (A Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Smart SVG techniques, from generative SVG grids to SVG paths with masks, grainy SVG gradients, cut-out effects and fractional SVG stars. Let’s look at some magical SVG techniques that you can use right away.
articles.title: Magical SVG Techniques

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Barry Pollard)
articles.description: At the end of 2021, the Chrome team shipped some functionality that has the ability to make or break sites meeting the Core Web Vitals. So, let’s learn a little bit more about the Back/Forward Cache (aka bfcache), and what you can do to test if your website is compatible with it.
articles.title: Performance Game Changer: Browser Back/Forward Cache

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joshua Mauldin)
articles.description: Let’s explore how to give and receive better feedback when working remotely — feedback that is actionable, specific, kind, and that won’t set you on edge. We’ll start by explaining when feedback sessions don’t work and how to prevent it.
articles.title: How To Give Effective Feedback Remotely

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stefan Baumgartner)
articles.description: When deploying websites, there’s rarely a one-size-fits-all solution. Some websites benefit from server-rendered pages, some prefer statically generating content upfront. In this article, Stefan explains how a CMS such as [Storyblok](https://www.storyblok.com/) can help you make your site more resilient without losing the flexibility to deliver time-relevant content.
articles.title: Resilience, Flexibility And Immediacy: Working With Headless Systems

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How difficult can it be to design a bulletproof language selector? It’s not as straightforward as one might think. We need to avoid redirects, decouple our language and country presets, allow for overrides, and use non-modal windows. Let’s dive in!
articles.title: Designing A Better Language Selector

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Josh Comeau)
articles.description: Developers often reach for UI frameworks like Bootstrap or Material UI, hoping that they’ll save a bunch of time and quickly build a professional-looking app. Unfortunately, things rarely work out this way. Let’s talk about it.
articles.title: You Don’t Need A UI Framework

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s welcome May with a new collection of wallpapers. Designed with love by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for May 2022.
articles.title: Make A Wish (May 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Steve Sewell)
articles.description: Introducing Partytown, a lightweight open-source solution that reduces execution delays due to third-party JavaScript by offloading third-party scripts to web workers, which run in background threads.
articles.title: How Partytown Eliminates Website Bloat From Third-Party Scripts

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nathan Smith)
articles.description: In this article, Nathan Smith explains how to create modal dialog windows with rich interaction that will only require authoring HTML in order to be used. They are based on Web Components that are currently supported by every major browser.
articles.title: CTA Modal: How To Build A Web Component

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: We should be able to measure how well a particular design solves a particular problem. Let’s explore design KPIs that capture user’s experience, how to measure them and how to keep both users and business stakeholders happy, over time.
articles.title: Boosting UX With Design KPIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ceara Crawshaw)
articles.description: When bad UX has lingered in a product for so long, it can feel like a mountain to overcome. In this article, Ceara Crawshaw shares her advice on how you can invoke joy and assure the quality in the work done on product teams.
articles.title: Preventing Bad UX Through Integrated Design Workflows

articles.author: Dillion Megida
articles.description: When you're designing a website or working on a project, you might want to use uppercase text for various reasons. Maybe you want to use an abbreviation or acronym, emphasize certain text, or use it for headings. There are multiple ways to uppercase text in HTML. The first way is
articles.title: All Caps in CSS - How to Uppercase Text with Style

articles.author: Manu Arora
articles.description: An online code execution platform lets you write code in your favourite programming language and run that code on the same platform.  You can ideally see an output of the program that you've written (for example, a binary search program written in JavaScript). Today, we are going to build
articles.title: How to Build a Code Editor with React that Compiles and Executes in 40+ Languages

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When working with float values (numbers with decimal values) in our Python program, we might want to round them up or down, or to the nearest whole number.  In this article, we'll see some built-in functionalities that let us round numbers in Python. And we'll see how to use
articles.title: Python Round to Int – How to Round Up or Round Down to the Nearest Whole Number

articles.author: Rinor Maloku
articles.description: Three years ago, I wrote an article titled "Back to Microservices with Istio" [https://medium.com/google-cloud/back-to-microservices-with-istio-p1-827c872daa53]  for Google Cloud Community. I published it there to reach people interested in the latest technologies built on top of Kubernetes.  At that point, Istio was a niche technology. But fast-forward three years, and:
articles.title: Learn Istio – How to Manage, Monitor, and Secure Microservices

articles.author: Ashutosh Krishna
articles.description: In this article, we will be covering an important topic, Security in Python.  We often download and install packages from PyPi but we're not sure about the vulnerabilities that might come with them.  So, in this tutorial, we will learn about an awesome tool called Snyk that helps
articles.title: How to Find and Fix Security Vulnerabilities Using Snyk

articles.author: Natalie Pina
articles.description: A boolean is a primitive value [https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Primitive] that represents either true or false. In Boolean contexts, JavaScript utilizes type casting [https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Type_Conversion] to convert values to true/false. There are implicit and explicit methods to convert values into their boolean counterparts. This article provides an overview of truthy and falsy values and
articles.title: How to Convert a Value to a Boolean in JavaScript

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: Are you aware of the millions of lines of code behind the applications and devices you use every day? Coding is used for many different purposes - more than you may realize. In this article, I will first go over what the term 'coding' actually means. Then, I will briefly
articles.title: What is Coding Used For?

articles.description: In C++, there are various data types like string, int, char, bool, float, and  double. Each of these data types have specific values that can be stored in them. When working with integers, we usually store them in an int data type. But this is only useful for whole
articles.title: Double VS Float in C++ – The Difference Between Floats and Doubles

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: There are some characters that are symbols which you don’t get access to on keyboards. In HTML, these characters are called entities and are reserved characters. articles.title: HTML Symbols – HTML Icon and Entity Code List
